text: Hey, do I need to buy a fancy, expensive processor / GPU to do my job as a machine learning engineer?

elements.text: Hey, do I need to buy a fancy, expensive processor / GPU to do my job as a machine learning engineer?

text: FWIW this might be a better question for <#C680MM7D4|random>, since it's not necessarily Julia-specific, but the two cents I can add here is that it's easier to do training and whatnot on a remote machine like AWS EC2. That will scale much better than running things locally. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: FWIW this might be a better question for

, since it's not necessarily Julia-specific, but the two cents I can add here is that it's easier to do training and whatnot on a remote machine like AWS EC2. That will scale much better than running things locally.

text: With that in mind, your local machine could just be a stone age computer as long as it has SSH

text: Depends on what you need and how you provision resources. Long-running GPU-enabled instances can be expensive, but CPU-only instances are quite reasonable (and even have a free tier if your resource requirements are sufficiently small)

elements.text: Depends on what you need and how you provision resources. Long-running GPU-enabled instances can be expensive, but CPU-only instances are quite reasonable (and even have a free tier if your resource requirements are sufficiently small)

text: Shameless plug: easiest way to try out Julia on EC2 is a VS Code instance on JuliaHub :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Shameless plug: easiest way to try out Julia on EC2 is a VS Code instance on JuliaHub

text: Amazon, Google, and others provide mechanisms to spin up an environment when needed. There are semi-manual ways starting with Kubernetes, to fully automatic machine learning environments.

elements.text: Amazon, Google, and others provide mechanisms to spin up an environment when needed. There are semi-manual ways starting with Kubernetes, to fully automatic machine learning environments.

text: Access to an old K80 GPU is $1.40/hr — more than the bare AWS EC2 instance but so much easier.

text:
Cheapest EC2 instance currently (t4g.nano): $0.0042/hr

Most expensive (x1e.32xl):
$26.688/hr :grimacing:

---

The real benefits of AWS comes from freeing up your local machine so you can do other work. Also all the other services that lets you tie things into EC2

> is that a single GPU?
Yes, technically it’s half a K80 board — The K80 board has two Tesla K80 GPUs

text:
<https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/pricing/on-demand/>

If you want cheaper instances you can sign a multi-year deal w/ AWS. Or move to Spot instances, however those will give you (I believe) a 60 second notice when the instance is being terminated because someone else is willing to pay more for it. So you’ll need to custom write some things to save states, etc.

elements.text: If you want cheaper instances you can sign a multi-year deal w/ AWS. Or move to Spot instances, however those will give you (I believe) a 60 second notice when the instance is being terminated because someone else is willing to pay more for it. So you’ll need to custom write some things to save states, etc.

text: I would assume so, since if an employer expects you to take data, duplicate (or worse, store) locally, and process it on your own hardware, they clearly do not understand what they're doing...

text: For personal stuff Colab or Kaggle kernels are the way to go. Can't beat free.

text: For work stuff I sure hope they're giving you a workstation or server with GPUs. Otherwise that's a big red flag...

elements.text: For work stuff I sure hope they're giving you a workstation or server with GPUs. Otherwise that's a big red flag...

text:
I haven’t used GCP in 5+ years, and briefly migrated things off of Azure onto AWS a few years ago.

But there’s a reason AWS holds ~33% of the cloud market share. Others are playing catch up most of the time.

With that said, if you’re just starting to look into this, definitely spend the time and do the research to see what fits your case best in terms of features vs. pricing.

And if you do decide on a GCP/Azure/Oracle setup, come to JuliaCloud org on GitHub and make a package to support it :smile:

elements.text:
I haven’t used GCP in 5+ years, and briefly migrated things off of Azure onto AWS a few years ago.

But there’s a reason AWS holds ~33% of the cloud market share. Others are playing catch up most of the time.

With that said, if you’re just starting to look into this, definitely spend the time and do the research to see what fits your case best in terms of features vs. pricing.

And if you do decide on a GCP/Azure/Oracle setup, come to JuliaCloud org on GitHub and make a package to support it
